data.first_aid_treatment_1: Give acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) to reduce fever and pain; do not give aspirin to children
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Ensure plenty of fluids (water, clear liquids, electrolyte solutions like Pedialyte) to prevent dehydration; offer small sips frequently

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Drink plenty of fluids (water, oral rehydration solutions, broth) in small sips every 15-30 minutes to prevent dehydration
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Rest at home and eat soft, bland foods when able; avoid fatty, spicy, and acidic foods that may worsen symptoms

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Drink plenty of fluids (water, oral rehydration solutions, broth) to prevent dehydration from diarrhea
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Rest at home and eat soft, bland foods; avoid anti-diarrheal medications like loperamide (Imodium) as they may worsen the infection

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) for fever and pain relief; do not give aspirin to children
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Drink plenty of fluids and eat soft, easy-to-chew foods; apply warm or cold compresses to swollen glands for comfort

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) for fever and throat pain; gargle with warm salt water (1/2 teaspoon salt in 1 cup warm water) 3-4 times daily
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Rest at home, drink plenty of clear fluids (water, warm tea, broth), and take prescribed antibiotics as directed by healthcare provider

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Give acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) to reduce fever and mouth pain; do not give aspirin to children
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Offer plenty of cool fluids and soft foods (yogurt, pudding, smoothies, ice pops) to ease mouth pain and prevent dehydration

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Take prescribed antibiotics (azithromycin, clarithromycin, or erythromycin) as directed by healthcare provider to reduce severity and spread
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Get plenty of rest, drink fluids frequently, eat small frequent meals to prevent vomiting, and use a cool mist humidifier to ease cough

symptoms: Sore and red throat with patches
data.first_aid_treatment_1: Take prescribed antibiotics (penicillin or amoxicillin) as directed; do not stop even if feeling better
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) for fever and pain; drink plenty of cool fluids and eat soft foods if throat is sore

symptoms: Watery discharge from nose that thickens and turns yellow or green
data.first_aid_treatment_1: Get plenty of rest and drink lots of fluids (water, warm tea, broth) to prevent dehydration and loosen mucus
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) for fever and aches; use saline nasal spray or cool mist humidifier to ease congestion

symptoms: Small white spots inside the cheeks
data.first_aid_treatment_1: Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) to reduce fever and discomfort; do not give aspirin to children under 16
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration, rest in a darkened room if light sensitivity occurs, and use a humidifier or damp cloth for cough relief

symptoms: Dry, cracked skin at mouth corners
Redness, irritation, and pain under dentures (denture stomatitis)
Slight bleeding if spots are scraped
Soreness or burning in the mouth
data.first_aid_treatment_1: Rinse mouth with warm salt water (1/2 teaspoon salt in 1 cup warm water) several times daily to ease pain and reduce inflammation
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Apply prescribed antifungal medication (nystatin oral gel, miconazole, or fluconazole) as directed by healthcare provider for 7-14 days

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) to manage fever, headache, and joint pain; do not give aspirin to children
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Get plenty of rest and drink fluids; the rash is not contagious once it appears, so no specific treatment is needed for mild cases

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Take acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) for fever and discomfort; do not give aspirin to children or teenagers
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Get plenty of rest at home and stay away from others (especially pregnant women) for at least 7 days after rash appears to prevent spread

symptoms: Itching on the scalp, neck, and ears
data.first_aid_treatment_1: Apply over-the-counter lice treatment shampoo containing permethrin (Nix) or pyrethrin (Rid) following package directions; repeat treatment in 7-10 days
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Use a fine-tooth nit comb daily for 2-3 weeks to remove lice and nits; wash bedding, clothes, and personal items in hot water (130°F) and dry on high heat

symptoms: Eye discharge (yellowish, greenish, or white; may cause crusting)
Redness in the white of the eye (sclera) or inner eyelid
Sensation of a foreign object in the eye
data.first_aid_treatment_1: Apply cold or warm compresses to eyes for a few minutes to reduce swelling and discomfort; clean away discharge with clean cotton or cloth
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Use artificial tears eye drops to relieve dryness; stop wearing contact lenses until symptoms resolve; wash hands frequently to prevent spread

data.first_aid_treatment_1: Wash sores gently with antibacterial soap and warm water 2-3 times daily, soaking off any crusts; pat dry with clean towel
data.first_aid_treatment_2: Apply prescribed antibiotic ointment or cream (mupirocin) 2-3 times daily and cover with waterproof bandage to prevent spreading; complete full antibiotic course
